column1: ▪ This is a book about outliers
column2: about men and women who do things that are out of the ordinary.

column1: ▪ For almost a generation
column2: psychologists around the world have been engaged in a spirited debate over a question that most of us would consider to have been settled years ago. The question is this: is there such a thing as innate talentThe obvious answer is yes. Not every hockey player born in January ends up playing at the professional level. Only some dothe innately talented ones.

column1: ▪ out-li-er \-
column2: l•(-9)r\ noun i: something that is situated away from or classed differently from a main or related body 2: a statistical observation that is markedly different in value from the others of the sample.

column1: ▪ Achievement is talent plus preparation. The problem with this view is that the closer psychologists look at the careers of the gifted
column2: the smaller the role innate talent seems to play and the bigger the role preparation seems to play.

column1: ▪ It is those who are successful
column2: in other words
column3: who are most likely to be given the kinds of special opportunities that lead to further success. It's the rich who get the biggest tax breaks. It's the best students who get the best teaching and most attention. And it's the biggest nineand ten-year-olds who get the most coaching and practice. Success is the result of what sociologists like to call “accumulative advantage.” The professional hockey player starts out a little bit better than his peers. And that little difference leads to an opportunity that makes that difference a bit bigger
column4: and that edge in turn leads to another opportunity
column5: which makes the initially small difference bigger stilland on and on until the hockey player is a genuine outlier. But he didn't start out an outlier. He started out just a little bit better.

column1: ▪ Everyone from all three groups started playing at roughly the same age
column2: around five years old. In those first few years
column3: everyone practiced roughly the same amount
column4: about two or three hours a week. But when the students were around the age of eight
column5: real differences started to emerge. The students who would end up the best in their class began to practice more than everyone else: six hours a week by age nine
column6: eight hours a week by age twelve
column7: sixteen hours a week by age fourteen
column9: until by the age of twenty they were practicingthat is
column10: purposefully and single-mindedly playing their instruments with the intent to get betterwell over thirty hours a week. In fact
column12: the elite performers had each totaled ten thousand hours of practice. By contrast
column13: the merely good students had totaled eight thousand hours
column14: and the future music teachers had totaled just over four thousand hours.

column1: ▪ Ericsson and his colleagues then compared amateur pianists with professional pianists. The same pattern emerged. The amateurs never practiced more than about three hours a week over the course of their childhood
column2: and by the age of twenty they had totaled two thousand hours of practice. The professionals
column3: on the other hand
column4: steadily increased their practice time every year
column5: until by the age of twenty they
column6: like the violinists
column7: had reached ten thousand hours.

column1: ▪ People don't rise from nothing. We do owe something to parentage and patronage.
▪ The striking thing about Ericsson's study is that he and his colleagues couldn't find any “naturals
column2: ” musicians who floated effortlessly to the top while practicing a fraction of the time their peers did. Nor could they find any “grinds
column3: ” people who worked harder than everyone else
column4: yet just didn't have what it takes to break the top ranks. Their research suggestes that once a musician has enough ability to get into a top music school
column5: the thing that distinguishes one performer from another is how hard he or she works. That's it. And what's more
column6: the people at the very top don't work just harder or even much harder than everyone else. They work much
column7: much harder.

column1: ▪ It makes a difference where and when we grew up. The culture we belong to and the legacies passed down by our forebears shape the patterns of our achievement in ways we cannot begin to imagine. It's not enough to ask what successful people are like
column2: in other words. It is only by asking where they are from that we can unravel the logic behind who succeeds and who doesn't.

column1: ▪ The idea that excellence at performing a complex task requires a critical minimum level of practice surfaces again and again in studies of expertise. In fact
column2: researchers have settled on what they believe is the magic number for true expertise: ten thousand hours.

column1: ▪ The emerging picture from such studies is that ten thousand hours of practice is required to achieve the level of mastery associated with being a world-class expertin anything

▪ Parents with a child born at the end of the calendar year often think about holding their child back before the start of kindergarten: it's hard for a five-year-old to keep up with a child born many months earlier. But most parents
column2: one suspects
column3: think that whatever disadvantage a younger child faces in kindergarten eventually goes away. But it doesn't. It's just like hockey. The small initial advantage that the child born in the early part of the year has over the child born at the end of the year persists. It locks children into patterns of achievement and underachievement
